Title: Përbindëshi (The Monster)
Notes: Banned for 25 years in Albania.

Title: Lolita (1955)
Notes: Banned for being "obscene".

Title: The Decameron
Notes: Banned in Australia from 1927 to 1936 and from 1938 to 1973.[5]

Title: The 120 Days of Sodom (1789)
Notes: Banned by the Australian Government in 1957 for obscenity.[6]

Title: Droll Stories
Notes: Banned for obscenity from 1901 to 1923 and 1928 to c.1973.[7][8]

Title: The Straits Impregnable
Notes: First edition published as a novel, second edition banned by the military censor in Australia under regulations of the War Precautions Act 1914.[9]

Title: Lady Chatterley's Lover (1928)
Notes: Banned from 1929 to 1965.[10][11]

Title: Rowena Goes Too Far (1931)
Notes: Banned in Australia because of customs belief that it "lacked sufficient claim to the literary to excuse the obscenity"[12]

Title: Brave New World
Notes: Banned in Australia from 1932 to 1937.[10]

Title: Age of Consent
Notes: Banned in Australia until 1962.[13]

Title: Forever Amber (1944)
Notes: Banned by Australia in 1945 as "a collection of bawdiness, amounting to sex obsession."[14][15]

Title: Borstal Boy
Notes: Banned shortly after its ban in Ireland in 1958.[16]

Title: Another Country
Notes: Banned in Australia by the Commonwealth Customs Department in February 1963. The Literature Censorship Board described it as "continually smeared with indecent, offensive and dirty epithets and allusions," but recommended that the book remain available to "the serious minded student or reader." The ban was lifted in May 1966.[17]

Title: Ecstasy and Me
Notes: Banned in Australia from 1967 until 1973.[10]

Title: The World Is Full of Married Men (1968)
Notes: Banned in Australia in 1968.[10]

Title: The Stud (1969)
Notes: Banned in Australia in 1969.[10][further explanation needed]

Title: The Anarchist Cookbook
Notes: Banned in Australia.[10][further explanation needed]

Title: How to make disposable silencers (1984)
Notes: An example of a class of books banned in Australia that "promote, incite or instruct in matters of crime or violence".[18][19]

Title: American Psycho
Notes: Sale and purchase was banned in the Australian State of Queensland. Now available in public libraries and for sale to people 18 years and older. Sale restricted to persons at least 18 years old in the other Australian states.[20]

Title: A Sneaking Suspicion (1995)
Notes: Banned by the New South Wales Department of Education and Communities from state schools May 6, 2015, on the basis of a "potential risk to students in the delivery of this material, if not taught sensitively and in an age appropriate manner."[21] The ban was lifted May 18, 2015.

Title: The Peaceful Pill Handbook (2007)
Notes: The book was initially restricted in Australia:[22] after review the 2007 edition was banned outright.[19][23][24]

Title: You: An Introduction (2008)
Notes: Banned by the New South Wales Department of Education and Communities from state schools May 6, 2015, on the basis of a "potential risk to students in the delivery of this material, if not taught sensitively and in an age appropriate manner."[21] The ban was lifted May 18, 2015.

Title: No Game No Life (Volumes 1, 2, 9)
Notes: Light novel volumes banned in Australia due to depiction which "in a way that is likely to cause offence to a reasonable adult, a person who is, or appears to be, a child under 18".[25]

Title: The Sorrows of Young Werther
Notes: Banned by the authorities in the Austrian territories ruled by the Habsburg monarchy.[26]

Title: Works
Notes: All of Marx's works were banned in Austria after the country was annexed by Nazi Germany.[26]

Title: Works
Notes: All of Einstein's works published up to 1938 were banned in Austria, after it was annexed by Nazi Germany.[26]

Title: Mein Kampf (1925)
Notes: In Austria, the Verbotsgesetz 1947 prohibits the printing of the book. It is illegal to own[citation needed] or distribute existing copies.[27] Following the general prohibition of advocating the Nazi Party or its aims in § 3 and of re-founding Nazi organizations in § 1, § 3 d. of the Verbotsgesetz states: "Whoever publicly or before several people, in printed works, disseminated texts or illustrations requests, encourages or seeks to induce others to commit any of the acts prohibited under § 1 or § 3, especially if for this purpose he glorifies or advertises the aims of the Nazi Party, its institutions or its actions, provided that it does not constitute a more serious criminal offense, will be punished with imprisonment from five to ten years, or up to twenty years if the offender or his actions are especially dangerous."[27]

Title: Rangila Rasul (1927)
Notes: Currently banned in India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh.[28]

Title: The Satanic Verses (1988)
Notes: Banned for blasphemy against Islam. Salman received a fatwa for his alleged blasphemy[29]

Title: Naree (1992)
Notes: Banned in Bangladesh in 1995,[30] though the ban was later lifted in 2000.[31]

Title: Lajja (1993)
Notes: Banned in Bangladesh,[32][33] and a few states of India. Other books by her were also banned in Bangladesh or in the Indian state of West Bengal. Amar Meyebela (My Girlhood, 2002), the first volume of her memoir, was banned by the Bangladeshi government in 1999 for "reckless comments" against Islam and the prophet Mohammad.[34] Utal Hawa (Wild Wind), the second part of her memoir, was banned by the Bangladesh government in 2002.[35] Ka (Speak up), the third part of her memoir, was banned by the Bangladeshi High Court in 2003. Under pressure from Indian Muslim activists, the book, which was published in West Bengal as Dwikhandita, was banned there also, some 3,000 copies were seized immediately.[36] The decision to ban the book was criticised by "a host of authors" in West Bengal,[37] but the ban was not lifted until 2005.[38][39] Sei Sob Ondhokar (Those Dark Days), the fourth part of her memoir, was banned by the Bangladesh government in 2004.[40][41]
